messages.content: can you check the grammar of the following: The shiny star sticker was itchy on his cheek. The cheap fabric of the plum-purple dress he wore piled on his hips and brushed roughly on his knees every step he took.

The grammar of the two sentences is correct.

* "The shiny star sticker was itchy on his cheek"
Here, the subject is "the shiny star sticker", the verb is "was itchy" and the object is "on his cheek". The sentence is in the past tense and the word order is correct.
* "The cheap fabric of the plum-purple dress he wore piled on his hips and brushed roughly on his knees every step he took."
Here, the subject is "the cheap fabric of the plum-purple dress", the verb is "piled on his hips and brushed roughly on his knees" and the object is "every step he took". The sentence is in the present participle and the word order is correct.

It is worth noting that the second sentence is a bit awkward in terms of word choice and phrasing, it could be rephrased in a more natural way.
